{"title":"Page 37","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"THE PARLOR MAGAZINE.
LITERARY WOMEN.
You ask my real name, and marvel that the " women of the
South " who are sufficiently gifted to write such pretty things,
send forth their effusions under a fictitious name.
Strange as this may seem, it becomes an absolute necessity in
Stone, Dr. Bl i 1 , II mi in 1 i \ntoinett Browne sort of
women. So you see that it is not false modesty, or cowardice,
that prevents me from placing my name before the public, but an
absolute necessity, as I have some inclination to mingle yet more
supported by a host of elegant bachelors, and some of them extremely good-looking! If it will not be asking too much, be
pleased to mention the fact that I might be prevailed upon to
interfere with their honorary degree of bachelor, which is very
respectable but not at all desirable.
I find that men are very dubious of literary women, and for
fear that I may become air object of their suspicion and contempt,
I withhold my name.
